newsitem.title: UK: Copper ends sleepy LME steady, still ranging.
newsitem.headline: Copper ends sleepy LME steady, still ranging.

text.p: Copper prices traded in a narrow $10 range on Wednesday on the LME, closing another subdued session little changed and still trapped in a wider technical band, traders said.

News that workers at Codelco's Salvador mine in Chile voted to go on strike from Saturday to demand wage rises did little to excite as output is just 85,000 tonnes a year. More impact is likely if there were to be a stoppage at Chino in the U.S.
Spreads softened for most of the day before ending at $32/42 backwardation, basis cash/threes, against $29/34 at one stage.
However, there is always the possibility of a flare up in nearby premiums, with September options declared next Wednesday and some crunch prompts falling due after that.

Generally, prices are seen in a broad range between $1,900 and $1,970 in the medium term with banks capping both ends of the band. A tighter $1,915/50 collar will serve as a jobbing range, traders added.
Last kerb business was at $1,943 a tonne, down just $1 from Tuesday's kerb close.
Aluminium activity was low-key, although the market's stability back above the $1,480 level was encouraging. The last trade was at $1,486.50, a $4.50 gain.
Nickel business was confined to a narrow range as well, with prices edging towards the highs to close at $7,350, a $10 gain from Tuesday.
Lead retained earlier gains above $800, which were notched up by Far Eastern buying and short-covering, closing at $805, a $10 advance.
Analysts were also watching developments at Gold Fields Namibia operations at Tsumeb which have been hit by strike action. The lead and copper smelters have been shut down.
Zinc trade was slow, both in futures and in the physical sector, and last LME business was at $1,024, down just $1.
Tin market conditions were equally slow, but prices held steady on the kerb, closing at an unchanged $6,175. Alloy was $7 higher at $1,285.
